item.title: Pakistani Taliban Thrive in Karachi
item.description: Extremists in neighborhoods of Pakistan's biggest metropolis dispense justice, extort cash and set off bombs, locals say, in a threat to the economy and coalition transit route.

item.title: Italy's President Moves to End Impasse
item.description: Italy's President started a day of talks with political leaders hoping to break the country's monthlong political impasse by naming someone who can form a government and avoid the specter of new elections.

item.title: Hopes Fade of Kim Rewriting Script
item.description: North Korea's recent provocations appear to be bolstering the authority of Kim Jong Eun at home, while eroding hopes that he would depart from his father's blueprint.

item.title: At Least 23 Killed in Iraq Blasts
item.description: A string of bombings targeting Shiite mosques in Iraq killed at least 23 people and wounded dozens, officials said.

item.title: Mandela, in Hospital, Making Progress
item.description: Nelson Mandela is making progress but remains in hospital after being admitted the day before to treat a recurring lung infection, South Africa's presidency said.

item.title: Cypriots Cast Blame as Banks Open
item.description: Cyprus's banks reopened from a nearly two-week hiatus with no sign of disorder, while the country's politicians pointed fingers over who was to blame for the financial sector's meltdown.

item.title: French Leader Lashes Out at Austerity
item.description: France's President François Hollande on Thursday said the time has come to mark a pause in the austerity programs that euro-zone countries have been putting in place in recent years in response to the euro sovereign-debt crisis.

item.title: Britain's Domestic Spy Agency Names New Chief
item.description: Britain's MI5 has chosen a new director, a 50-year-old ornithologist with counterterrorism experience in the Middle East and Northern Ireland.

item.title: Pope Breaks From Tradition
item.description: Pope Francis washed and kissed the feet of inmates—including women and Muslims—at a youth detention center, a twist to a traditional ceremony that emphasized his goal of placing Roman Catholicism's loftiest office at the service of the downtrodden.

item.title: Former Top Regulator Gets Provincial Post in China
item.description: China formally appointed its former top securities regulator, prominent reformer Guo Shuqing, as acting governor of Shandong province.

item.title: Police Give Details in Tycoon's Death
item.description: Russian tycoon Boris Berezovsky was found dead on his bathroom floor with his neck bound and a similar piece of material attached to a shower rail, a police officer told a coroner's inquest.

item.title: Post-Coup Calm in Central Africa
item.description: The head of a regional peacekeeping force in the Central African Republic said South Africa pulled half of its 200 troops from the country, though South Africa declined to comment on deployment numbers, amid reports of relative calm in the capital.

item.title: Belgium Rushes to Find Budget Solution
item.description: Belgium rushed to finalize budget negotiations, with ministers from the six-party governing coalition desperately hunting for ways to comply with recently relaxed European Union budget goals and avoid fines.

item.title: Deadly Attack Hits Syrian University
item.description: Mortar shells slammed into a cafeteria at Damascus University on Thursday, killing at least 10 people and wounding 20, according to state media and officials.

item.title: Turkey Denies Expulsions
item.description: Turkey denied that it had deported Syrians from one of Turkey's sprawling refugee camps after riots broke out the day before, marking the latest in a series of incidents to erupt at Turkish camps.

item.title: Pistorius Bail Restrictions Eased
item.description: Lawyers for murder-accused Olympic athlete Oscar Pistorius won an appeal to relax the bail conditions imposed on the athlete, including the right to travel.

item.title: Czech Ex-Leader Escapes Charge
item.description: The Czech Constitutional Court rejected treason charges against the country's former president on procedural grounds, saying that since the euro-skeptic politician has already left office there is no point in a trial aimed at removing him.

item.title: In Germany, Some Want to Boogie Every Day of the Year
item.description: The German ban on dancing on Good Friday has drawn protests.

item.title: U.S. Soccer Could Use a Good Crisis
item.description: A loss by the U.S. men's soccer team in Mexico on Tuesday would likely revive concerns that this side isn't good enough to make it through an increasingly competitive regional qualifying tournament.

item.title: Arise! Arise! The British Are…Acting!
item.description: On big and small screens, the juicy Yank parts are going to people with names like Day-Lewis. How to fight back.

item.title: Photos of the Day: March 28
item.description: In today's pictures, people take a swim in Brazil, workers stage a strike in Hong Kong, a man cleans a huge pan in India, and more.
